headline.main: STOCKMAN HEARING SUGGESTS FUTURE BUDGET CONFLICTS

results.snippet: David A. Stockman, who has been designated President-elect Ronald Reagan's budget chief, answered a Senate committee's questions for more than five hours today in a confirmation hearing that produced harbingers of conflicts over cutting the budget....

byline.original: By EDWARD COWAN, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: David A. Stockman, who has been designated President-elect Ronald Reagan's budget chief, answered a Senate committee's questions for more than five hours today in a confirmation hearing that produced harbingers of conflicts over cutting the budget. Representative Stockman, a Michigan Republican, acknowledged that there would be opposition from various quarters when the new administration became specific about applying Mr. Reagan's campaign pledge to eliminate ''waste, fraud and abuse.'' He told the Governmental Affairs Committee that there was no budget line labeled ''waste, fraud and abuse.'' ''They have other names and those names have constituencies,'' Mr. Stockman said.

headline.main: 'HANGER 18' A TALE ABOUT A CAPTURED U.F.O.

results.snippet: ''Hangar 18'' is the sort of melodrama that pretends to be skeptical, but requires that everyone watching it be profoundly gullible. It's about the efforts of the White House Chief of Staff to hide from the public the fact that the Air Force has...
results.lead_paragraph: ''Hangar 18'' is the sort of melodrama that pretends to be skeptical, but requires that everyone watching it be profoundly gullible. It's about the efforts of the White House Chief of Staff to hide from the public the fact that the Air Force has caught a flying saucer and is studying it at a secret Texas base. The reason for this super-Watergate cover-up is obscure, though it eventually costs dozens of lives and involves most of the members of the Central Intelligence Agency, the Federal Bureau of Investigation and maybe even the Boy Scouts, all of whom are sworn to secrecy.

headline.main: AT THE BOHEMIAN CLUB, MEN JOIN, WOMEN SERVE

results.snippet: A few years ago a scholar examining the sociology of ''ruling class cohesiveness'' decided that the Bohemian Club of San Francisco's annual summer encampment was a gathering of ''the decision-makers and opinion molders of corporate America.''  ...

byline.original: By WALLACE TURNER, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: A few years ago a scholar examining the sociology of ''ruling class cohesiveness'' decided that the Bohemian Club of San Francisco's annual summer encampment was a gathering of ''the decision-makers and opinion molders of corporate America.'' ''The men of Bohemia are drawn in large measure from the corporate leadership of the United States,'' the scholar, G. William Domhoff, wrote in ''The Bohemian Grove and Other Retreats,'' published by Harper & Row in 1973. ''They include in their numbers directors from major corporations in every sector of the American economy.'' Former President Richard M. Nixon was a member, and perhaps still is; membership lists are confidential. Herbert Hoover, who called it ''the greatest men's party on earth,'' was a longtime member, as is former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Sr. Mr. Brown's son, the current Governor, never joined.

results.snippet: Jolted by last year's recession and burdened by debt, Eastern Air Lines Inc. has been staggered further by powerful competition from other lines.   Under Frank Borman, its ex-astronaut president, chairman and chief executive, Eastern itself has...
results.lead_paragraph: Jolted by last year's recession and burdened by debt, Eastern Air Lines Inc. has been staggered further by powerful competition from other lines. Under Frank Borman, its ex-astronaut president, chairman and chief executive, Eastern itself has been competing vigorously: last year it announced low fares to gain passengers in the New York-toCalifornia market -and spurred a price war. This month it has moved to protect its Air Shuttle and generate transcontinental business by giving shuttle passengers coupons good for flights to California at half price. And Eastern is considering a merger with debt-ridden Braniff International, which could give it a leg up on Latin American routes, where Braniff has been strong. But Eastern's overall performance has been ''disappointing,'' Mr. Borman conceded, solemn-faced, in an interview yesterday. For the first nine months of 1980, the airline lost $35 million, compared with earnings of $42 million in the 1979 period. The red ink included an operating loss of $5 million, on operating revenues of $2.56 billion, and reflected the heavy cost of financing equipment. Some analysts predict that Eastern's 1980 loss will exceed $50 million, compared with a 1979 net of $57.6 million.

results.snippet: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee today overwhelmingly recommended the confirmation of Alexander M. Haig Jr.  as Secretary of State. Two Democrats who had clashed with him over the Watergate scandals cast the only dissenting votes.   The...

byline.original: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee today overwhelmingly recommended the confirmation of Alexander M. Haig Jr. as Secretary of State. Two Democrats who had clashed with him over the Watergate scandals cast the only dissenting votes. The 15-to-2 vote minimized the chances of a sharp fight on the Senate floor, but Senator Charles H. Percy, the Illinois Republican who heads the committee, said that because there would be some opposition, no attempt would be made to force a vote on Inauguration Day, next Tuesday. He said he expected a vote the next day.

headline.main: TV View; BUSINESSLIKE VS. HOMESPUN IN THE EARLY MORNING

results.snippet: Television comes its closest to functioning as an appliance during the prime early-morning hours, when ''The Today Show'' and ''Good Morning America'' hold sway. Anyone watching these programs is probably doing other things as well; this is the...
results.lead_paragraph: Television comes its closest to functioning as an appliance during the prime early-morning hours, when ''The Today Show'' and ''Good Morning America'' hold sway. Anyone watching these programs is probably doing other things as well; this is the time of day when the audience is least likely to be sitting still. So, television, which in the evening can hope to hold the viewer's full attention, must settle in the morning for a fleeting, collaborative role. The best it can do, along with the toaster and the coffeepot, is help send you on your way. What can television ideally offer when it exerts only a partial influence? Conciseness is the key to programming on both ''Good Morning America'' and ''Today,'' which run from 7 A.M. to 9 A.M. and consist of quick, compact segments on a variety of topics. Health, finance, child-rearing, home improvement, consumer news - any one of these subjects can lend itself to a five-minute spot that's over before you burn breakfast, giving way quickly to another snippet of comparable interest. Short segments like these are most effective when they provide enough information to pique one's curiosity but not too much to bog down. At this time of day, speed and economy are everything. Morning television works most efficiently when it delivers only as much detail as the busy, distracted viewer can handle and no more.

results.snippet: * Allegheny Ludlum Steel Corporation, Pittsburgh, has elected George W. Tippins chairman and Richard P. Simmons president and chief executive officer.   * American Public Energy Company, Dallas, has named James C.  Osborne executive vice president...
results.lead_paragraph: * Allegheny Ludlum Steel Corporation, Pittsburgh, has elected George W. Tippins chairman and Richard P. Simmons president and chief executive officer. * American Public Energy Company, Dallas, has named James C. Osborne executive vice president and chief operating officer. * Dillon, Read & Company, an investment banking firm, has elected Dennis T. Melchior and Lorenzo D. Weisman senior vice presidents.
